title: fa.functional analysis - Differential equation
body: Consider $u = u(\phi,\psi)$ where $\phi = \phi(x)$ and $\psi =\psi(x)$ are both analytic function. The following equation $$\partial_x u - u\partial_x (\phi-\psi)=0$$ has a trivial solution $u(\phi,\psi) = c\,e^{\phi-\psi}$ , where $c$ is a constant. Note that $u(\phi,\psi) = c\,e^{\phi-\psi}$ solves the above equation for whatever function of $x$ $\phi$ and $\psi$ is. This equation doesn't seems to be an ordinary differential equation because none function of $x$ whas found. Is it a functional differential equation? I'm wondering to solve the following equation $$\partial_x v - v\partial_x(\phi+\psi) = e^{\phi-\psi} - e^{-\phi+\psi}$$ where the aim is to find $v = v(\phi,\psi)$ . How do I call (or classify) differential equations where the aim is to find a function that depends of another function like those shown above? PS: Such equations appears in the context of algebraic description of Backlund Transformation via gauge transformation. fa.functional-analysis differential-equations functional-equations Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jul 25, 2020 at 22:17 Jogean Carvalho 1 $\endgroup$ 2 $\begingroup$ If I understand correctly you want a solution $y(x)$ of the ODE $$y'(x)-y(x)\big(\phi'(x)-\psi'(x)\big)= e^{\phi(x)-\psi(x)}-e^{-\phi(x)+\psi(x)},$$ AND you want this solution to be of the form $y(x):=v(\phi(x),\psi(x))$ for some $2$-variable function $v(t,s)$. Is this the problem? $\endgroup$ Pietro Majer –  Pietro Majer 2020-07-25 22:29:14 +00:00 Commented Jul 25, 2020 at 22:29 $\begingroup$ If so, it seems the factorization is quite a disjoint problem from the linear ODE. The latter can be easily integrated and has a general solution of some form $y(x)=Y(x,\phi(x),\psi(x),C)$. So I'd say all you need is to write $x$ in terms of the given functins $\phi$ and $\psi$ as $$x=w(\phi(x),\psi(x)),$$ for some $2$-variable function $w$, and then define $$v(t,s):= Y(w(t,s),t,s,C)$$ so that $v(\phi(x), \psi(x))=y(x)$ $\endgroup$ Pietro Majer –  Pietro Majer 2020-07-25 22:51:24 +00:00 Commented Jul 25, 2020 at 22:51 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
